title: Starknet L2 initiates test transactions from Ethereum mainnet - crypto.news
summary: Starknet, an Ethereum layer-2 scaling solution, has initiated test transactions from the mainnet ahead of the launch of its native token, STRK, expected by Q2 2024. The official Starknet address made seven cross-chain transactions, with less than three STRK tokens transferred. This is part of an on-chain test exercise to prepare for the rollout of STRK. The Starknet Foundation has allocated 1.8 billion STRK tokens for distribution, including network rebates and community rewards. Additionally, STRK is set to onboard additional utilities after a community vote approved it as a valid transaction fee payment currency. The L2 network, built by Starkware Industries, uses zero-knowledge rollup technology to scale Ethereum's network while maintaining on-chain security and transparency. As of Jan. 15, Starknet has over $169 million in total value locked.

title: Solana takes break from eating Ethereum's lunch — for now - Blockworks
summary: Solana, a competitor to Ethereum, has seen significant growth in market capitalization and price over the past year, with its market cap nearly quintupling and its price quadrupling. Meanwhile, other cryptocurrencies such as BNB and ADA have also seen growth in market cap and price, with BNB reaching about 33% of ether's cap and ADA reaching up to 25% during the last bull market. Despite Solana's growth, Ethereum remains the dominant player in the market, but Solana is well on track to become its primary competitor based on market cap growth.

title: Etherum Aims for Scalability, Bitcoin Maintains Fork Conservatism - CCN.com
summary: Ethereum is planning to scale its platform through the Dencun upgrade, which will introduce Proto-Danksharding and stateless clients to increase transaction processing capacity. This is in contrast to Bitcoin, which has been resistant to change and has maintained a single-minded vision aligned with Satoshi Nakamoto's original white paper. Bitcoin's block size has been capped at 1 MB since 2010, limiting its transaction processing capacity to around five transactions per second. Ethereum, on the other hand, has a history of implementing upgrades through consensus among developers, node operators, and token holders. The Dencun upgrade is expected to occur in mid-2024 and will lay the groundwork for the introduction of full Danksharding in later upgrades.

title: Ethereum vs Ethereum Classic: 5 Key Differences Between ETH and ETC - CoinGape
summary:
Sure, here's a summary of the article in less than 256 tokens:

Ethereum and Ethereum Classic are two different blockchains that emerged from the same network due to a hard fork in 2016. Key differences include:

* Origin: Ethereum Classic was the original blockchain that remained immutable after the hard fork, while Ethereum was the new network that implemented a hard fork to undo the hack.
* Consensus mechanism: Ethereum transitioned from Proof-of-Work (PoW) to Proof-of-Stake (PoS) after the "Ethereum Merge" event in September 2022, while Ethereum Classic remained a PoW network.
* Token supply and monetary policy: Ethereum has no fixed token supply, while Ethereum Classic's token supply is fixed at around 210.7 million, and its inflation rate is capped at 4.5%.
* Market value and community: Ethereum has a larger market value and user base compared to Ethereum Classic, with a wider focus on functionalities and dApps.
* Network

Solana's native token SOL has surged by over 700% since the end of 2022, driven by dedicated developers working on interesting projects. The Solana Foundation reports a continual influx of professional developers and a maturing developer environment. Despite its recent establishment, the developer ecosystem has rapidly expanded, positioning Solana as a top contender. The Solana Foundation's hackathon witnessed participation from 151 countries, with representatives from 65 countries submitting final projects. Nigeria had the highest number of registered projects, with 273 submissions and 41 winners.
